items.title: Appdirs can return non writable directories
items.body:
It seems like appdirs can return a directory that cannot be written to.

Is this an expected feature?

https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/issues/4664

From the original user:

> For my flask app's service, the user is a no-login user, and somehow this resolves to /var/www/.
The user doesn't have permissions to create a directory there, so the flask app crashes with a PermissionError raised from.

items.title: shoud the shebang "#!/usr/bin/env python" removed from appdirs.py?
items.body:
On fedora31 docker image,   there is only python3,  and there is no python link to python3,
Error  "python: command not found"  will be reported on this kind of system.

should we remove the shebang or change it to python3?

items.title: Invalid e-mail in maintainers
items.body:
The e-mail address `github@srid.name` as [indicated in maintainers](https://github.com/ActiveState/appdirs/blob/f8a8e9dcbdcf212f05e610957ba6ff55294049f0/setup.py#L53) points to a non-existent domain.

```
$ dig srid.name

```

items.title: Add github actions to make a new release
items.body: It seems that this package has not made a new release for a long time. The lastest version is 1.4.3 and was released on Mar 7, 2017. Now github actions has been available, so maybe github actions could be added to make a new release  automatically.

items.title: Publish 1.4.4 to pypi
items.body:
I'm writing a program that could really use a more recent version of this package - specifically the changes made in https://github.com/ActiveState/appdirs/commit/c99f3303007a1803cbaa23fc2830336ec551460b .
Is there a current timeline on publishing 1.4.4?

Edit: obviously this lib is small enough to just include in my project, but I would like to avoid "static linking" if possible

items.title: Don't use pywin32 for Windows
items.body: The current logic falls back to ctypes, which is always available. It would be useful to just drop the dependence on pywin32 completely.

items.title: Error: Failed to fetch py27-appdirs: Connection time-out
items.body:
I'm a MacPorts user. My PowerMac G5 no longer upgrades due to `appdirs-1.4.3`. The problem has been occurring for several months. See [py27-appdirs: fetch failure](https://trac.macports.org/ticket/55552).

I don't know if i386 or x86_64 Macs have problems with  `appdirs-1.4.3` because I don't use Macs. (I keep the old G5 around for testing software on a big-endian powerpc processor).

As upstream, please work with MacPorts to solve the problems with `appdirs-1.4.3`.

Please forgive me for this bug report. I'm at wit's end trying to solve it. Thank you in advance.

items.title: AIX support
items.body: There is a fair amount of Python development on that platform that it is worth adding. Lower priority than other items in the queue, but want to make sure its here.

items.title: With python3.4 in Windows 7 user_config_dir() returns a invalid patch
items.body:
I have this issue working with python3.4 in Windows 7, the path returned by user_config_dir() if not a valid path, in Python3 strings are unicode so there is not need to scape special caracters.

>>> import appdirs
>>> appdirs.user_config_dir()
'C:\\Users\\Contabilidad\\AppData\\Local'

items.title: temp dir
items.body:
hi! 
It will be very useful (at least for me), if there would be `user_temp_dir` or `system_temp_dir`.
Are there any plans to add one?
Thanks!

items.title: Don't get version from appdirs.__version__
items.body:
Because appdirs is used by setuptools now, when the setup script is run, a different version of appdirs may be in the path ahead of the source distribution, causing the version to be determined indirectly.

https://github.com/benjaminp/six/issues/188
https://github.com/buildout/buildout/issues/382


cc @alimanfoo

items.title: Java port available
items.body:
Not an issue, sorry.  I ported this to java since it's a library I can't really live without and Java is something you sometimes need: https://github.com/Rendaw/appdirsj

I kept the license of course, but please tell me if I've botched any attributions or other details (if you care).

items.title: site_cache_dir?
items.body: I may be mistaken but isn't there a site cache directory on most systems too? Specifically interested in FHS compliant systems, isn't it /var/cache/<app> ?

items.title: use freedesktops pyxdg
items.body:
Instead of just extracting the envvar it may be a more robust aproach worth investigating to utilise [pyxdg](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/pyxdg/) to handle `XDG` environments .

Then again, it seems like a relatively heavy dependency. My point was to just put it out here in case you were not aware of it.

items.title: *_config_dir incorrect for darwin
items.body: Application preferences belong in ~/Library/Preferences or /Library/Preferences to separate them from general application data.  The current implementation returns the same location as user_data_dir and site_data_dir, which is ~/Library/Application Support and /Library/Application Support.

items.title: Reformatting `setup.py` summary
items.body: These lines may need some help ( https://github.com/ActiveState/appdirs/blob/57f2bc44a8bca99bac6c57496c8b3fdea26f94d5/setup.py#L23-L24 ).

items.title: user_config_dir appends directory name twice in Windows
items.body:
running the following:
appdirs.user_config_dir('MyApp')

returns:
C:\Documents and Settings\username\Local Settings\Application Data\MyApp\MyApp

expected result:
C:\Documents and Settings\username\Local Settings\Application Data\MyApp

items.title: Convenience wrapper has stricter signature than wrapped functions
items.body: The convenience wrapper AppDirs requires an `appname` parameter, whereas the underlying functions do not. The wrapper should default to None for appname.

items.title: Thoughts on a few changes
items.body:
Hello there!

We're investigating using appdirs inside of pip over in pypa/pip#1733 and a few issues came up. We were wondering if y'all would be interested in any of these changes at all.
1. Make the "vendor" argument optional even on Windows, and simply omit it if it is not provided. While it is true that technically the vendor is a required directory on Windows, it's not a very well followed standard and a lot of things violate it.
2. Ability to override the default values, specifically so we can move the `/etc/xdg/<foo>` directory to `/etc/<foo>`. Again while it is true that the XDG spec does mandate defaulting to `/etc/xdg` looking at a few Linux installs it appears that generally the only things that actually _do_ default to `/etc/xdg` instead of `/etc` are actual desktop apps and not CLI programs like pip.

I don't have a problem submitting these pull requests but I wanted to see if these were things that y'all were willing to have!

items.title: _winreg is renamed in python3
items.body:
`_winreg` got renamed to `winreg` in python3. Instead of `import _winreg`, this should be done:

```
if PY3:
    import winreg as _winreg
else:
    import _winreg
```

items.title: Maintained
items.body:
Hey, this isn't really an issue exactly, but I was wondering if this project was still maintained? I see a handful of commits over the past year but the last release was 3 years ago.

It's OK if it's not :) I just need this functionality and I don't want to rely on an unmaintained library!

items.title: Please release 1.3.0
items.body: Please release 1.3.0 to make it easier to use the new user_config_dir function.

items.title: Does not work in Jython on Windows or Mac.
items.body: The `*_dir()` methods do not work on Windows or Mac in Jython. In Jython `sys.platform` is `'javaX.Y.Z'` which incorrectly causes the paths to treated as Unix/Posix paths. Would you be open to a pull request to fix this?

items.title: Debian package
items.body: It would be great to have a debian package for appdirs so that other packages could depend on it. Would you be open to submitting appdirs as a debian package?

items.title: Windows 7: user_data_dir returns type 'unicode'
items.body:
test_dirs and test_helpers fail on Windows 7 because user_data_dir returns a unicode string.

BTW, @mcepl, the default error reporting verbosity is insufficient. I am not familiar with unittest and used to py.test's default verbose error reporting, how does one increase the verbosity of error reporting to obtain the details of the returned values which were tested?

I had to manually call the function myself in a console to get its type. Py.test does that for you automatically.

(Probably my question isn't clear, I'll provide an this evening an example output to get the gist of it.)

items.title: Unix: Logs are not cached files
items.body: Because logs cannot be regenerated easily (or at all) after removal, they should not be placed in the XDG cache directories. They should be placed instead in one of the XDG data directories.

items.title: use sys.platform == "win32" instead of sys.platform.startswith("win")
items.body:
As suggested in the discussion at

https://github.com/eddyp/appdirs/commit/9198f6cf567cd5669aad93943e68996bc6999788#commitcomment-2835016

`sys.platform.startswith("win")` tests can be safely replaced with `sys.platform == "win32"`

items.title: Travis-CI support
items.body: We should encourage TDD and having Travis-CI support is The Right Thing™ (despite being locked into one-site API).

items.title: write tests
items.body: `test_api.py` only tests the _type_ of the return values. we need tests to cover the behaviour of appdirs functions (i.e., return _values_) on _each_ platform.

items.title: Please conform to XDG standard, instead of breaking it for everybody
items.body:
The XDG standard says user-specific data files should be written in $XDG_DATA_HOME which defaults to $HOME/.local/share.

Appdirs **explicitly** breaks XDG_DATA_HOME specification and returns a path based on $XDG_CONFIG_HOME, ~/.config/appname instead of ~/.local/share/appname for user_data_dir.

This is not at all "subject to some interpretation", this is as clear as day in the XDG spec:

http://standards.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html

Quote:
There is a single base directory relative to which **user-specific data** files should be written. This directory is **defined by the environment variable $XDG_DATA_HOME**

and later:

$XDG_DATA_HOME defines the base directory relative to which **user specific data files should be stored**. If $XDG_DATA_HOME is either not set or empty, a **default equal to $HOME/.local/share** should be used.

No ifs or buts. It doesn't matter at all if some apps decide not to respect the standard, a library should do the right thing, not break standards for everybody 'just because'.

To fix this, commit 362f390237fa59bd4202b841b68b3217372fc089 should be reverted.

items.title: Release archives lack test/api.doctests file
items.body:
```
$ ./test.py 
appdirs/doctests/api ... ERROR
appdirs/doctests/internal ... ok

======================================================================

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_appdirs.py", line 18, in test_api
    test = doctest.DocFileTest("api.doctests")
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/doctest.py", line 2424, in DocFileTest
    doc, path = _load_testfile(path, package, module_relative)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/doctest.py", line 219, in _load_testfile
    with open(filename) as f:
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: './api.doctests'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 2 tests in 0.079s

FAILED (1 error)
```

It seems that the file should be added to `MANIFEST.in`.

items.title: It should be possible to call the functions without arguments.
items.body:
If I want to get the path to e.g. the user data directory, I have to pass a phoney app name (or an empty string) to the `user_data_dir` function, then clip the string manually. I think it should be possible to just call the function without arguments to get the data directory path. The same should work for the cache dir and log dir functions. Examples: 
>>> user_data_dir()
'/Users/tomas/Library/Application Support'
>>> user_cache_dir()
'/Users/tomas/Library/Caches'
This is an extremely tiny change that would make the library much more user friendly to people in my situation. I would fix it myself, but in this case I think it would be orders of magnitude less work for you to fix this issue than for me to start forking the project and requesting a merge. Anyway, thanks for making a great library that has saved me a lot of work! :-)

items.title: crazy user_log_dir (double version) on Ubuntu
items.body:
This is where PyPM's log file is stored when latest appdirs (git master) is used:

```
~/.cache/pypm/1.1/log/1.1/pypm.log
```

Double version in path? PyPM uses `join(user_log_dir, "pypm.log")` (to the effect). Running stock appdirs on Ubuntu:

```
$ python lib/appdirs.py
[...]
user_log_dir: /home/sridharr/.cache/myapp/1.0/log/1.0
```

No, that's not good.

items.title: user_config_dir
items.body:
We need `user_config_dir`. Because, on Unix user_data_dir points to `~/.local/share/<appname>` but we have nothing to use `~/.config/<appname>`.

On Mac? user_config_dir == user_data_dir? `~/Library/Application Support/<appname>`

On Windows? user_config_dir == user_data_dir?

When I inspect my Linux VM, all apps tend to use ~/.config for storing stuff instead of ~/.local/share.

Also, `~/.config/pypm.conf` (or `~/.config/pypm/client.conf`) would be the most appropriate place to put the pypm configuration file.

Thoughts?

items.title: site_data_dir is wrong on Mac
items.body:
site_data_dir's value is actually `'~/Library/Application Support'` on Mac, while the function comment says otherwise (`/Library/Application Support`)

```
-- using `AppDirs`
user_data_dir: /Users/sridharr/Library/Application Support/SuperApp/1.0
site_data_dir: /Users/sridharr/Library/Application Support/SuperApp/1.0
```

items.title: log_file_path
Should follow XDG spec for unix
items.body:
http://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/cvay0/a_small_python_module_for_determining_appropriate/c0vk29s
"Configs go in ~/.config and data can go in ~/.local/share/data"

http://standards.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html

items.title: can't use Carbon for Python 3 on Mac: what's the fix?
items.body:
hsoft noted on this reddit post http://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/cvay0/a_small_python_module_for_determining_appropriate/

> hsoft
> Looks nice. However, it won't work on python 3 for OS X because it uses the Carbon module :(
